The claim was supported by information f: s Pregnancy Risk Assessment Monitoring System survey, which asked new mothers about their intentions to get pregnant.
The survey found that in 2010: 46.4% of new mothers surveyed in Oregon said they were not trying to get pregnant, supporting the claim that nearly half of all pregnancies in the state were unintended.
The claim was also backed up by a simila: which found that nearly half of all pregnancies in the United States were unintended according to the Guttmacher Institute's research.
The definition of an unintended pregnanc: according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Oregon Health Authority, is when a woman wanted to be pregnant later or not at all, further supporting the claim's authenticity.
